title: Romance-Specific Prohibited Words List
description: Genre-specific prohibited patterns for romance fiction. Use this list ONLY when processing romance content where emotional authenticity is critical. These patterns address AI defaults in romance: generic emotional escalation, relationship arc clichés, and mechanical attraction language.
usage_note: This list is OPTIONAL - include only when the author has explicitly indicated this is romance fiction and wants genre-specific pattern detection.
when_to_use: Author is writing contemporary romance, paranormal romance, or historical romance
Author requests genre-specific AI pattern detection
Emotional intimacy and relationship authenticity are priorities
Author wants to avoid mechanical emotional escalation patterns
when_to_skip: Literary fiction with intentional emotional escalation
Character-specific voice that may include these patterns naturally
Author has not indicated this is romance fiction

romance_specific_bans.description: Romance fiction has specific AI defaults that appear with mechanical repetition. These patterns undermine emotional authenticity by substituting generic descriptor for specific character moment.
romance_specific_bans.detection_rule: Patterns specific to romance writing: generic emotion escalation ('need', 'want' used repeatedly without specificity), physical attraction defaults (chemistry, electricity, magnetic), emotional vulnerability clichés ('walls coming down', 'defenses crumbling'), possession language, and relationship-arc predictability patterns.
common_ai_patterns: nothing would ever be the same
allowed_replacements_only: She wanted him. Wanted to know what he tasted like, what his hands felt like on bare skin.
The tension between them was thick enough to cut.
He looked at her and she forgot what she was saying.
[Show specific consequence of attraction, not generic emotional state]

replacement_strategy.preferred: Delete generic escalation. Show specific consequence: what she does, what changes in their interaction, concrete sensory moment.
replacement_strategy.simple_alternative: Replace 'need crashed over her' with 'She wanted him. Specifically his mouth, his hands, his certainty.'
replacement_strategy.alternative_2: Replace 'walls crumbled' with specific behavior change: 'She stopped keeping him at arm's length. Stopped protecting herself.'
replacement_strategy.never_use: These clichéd emotional escalators. They're identical across all AI romance.

bad_ai_writing: Need crashed over her as he pulled her close.
The chemistry between them was undeniable.
Her walls came crashing down at his touch.
He made her feel alive for the first time in years.
good_human_writing: She wanted him. Specifically his mouth, his hands, the certainty in his voice.
When he spoke to her, she couldn't think about anything else.
She'd spent three years keeping men at a distance. Not him. Not anymore.
He touched her and she felt herself shifting, becoming someone else.
'When did this happen?' she asked, and he smiled: 'For me? The first day.'

romance_specific_bans.pattern_matching_instruction: Identify generic emotional escalation and relationship-arc clichés specific to romance: walls/defenses crumbling, chemistry/electricity language, 'changed everything', possession language, emotional undoing. Replace with specific character action or moment showing what attraction looks like for these particular characters.
